content.question: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. A student is given a sample of <math alttext="C u S O 4, solid"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> that contains a solid impurity that is soluble and colorless. The student wants to determine the amount of <math alttext="C u S O 4"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in the sample and decides to use a spectrophotometer. First, the student prepares a calibration graph by measuring the absorbances of <math alttext="C u S O 4, aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> solutions of known concentrations. The graph is shown below. (a) The student dissolves the entire impure sample of <math alttext="C u S O 4, solid"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in enough distilled water to make <math alttext="100 decimal point milliliters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100.</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of solution. Then the student measures the absorbance of the solution and observes that it is <math alttext="0.30"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Determine the concentration of <math alttext="C u S O 4, aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the solution.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. A student is given a sample of <math alttext="C u S O 4, solid"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> that contains a solid impurity that is soluble and colorless. The student wants to determine the amount of <math alttext="C u S O 4"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in the sample and decides to use a spectrophotometer. First, the student prepares a calibration graph by measuring the absorbances of <math alttext="C u S O 4, aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> solutions of known concentrations. The graph is shown below. (a) The student dissolves the entire impure sample of <math alttext="C u S O 4, solid"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in enough distilled water to make <math alttext="100 decimal point milliliters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100.</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of solution. Then the student measures the absorbance of the solution and observes that it is <math alttext="0.30"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Determine the concentration of <math alttext="C u S O 4, aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the solution.

(b) Calculate the number of moles of <math alttext="C u S O 4"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> that were in the impure sample of <math alttext="C u S O 4, solid"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) In addition to the number of moles of <math alttext="C u S O 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> calculated in part <math alttext="b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>(b)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, what other quantity must be measured in order to calculate the mass percentage of <math alttext="C u S O 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in the impure sample of <math alttext="C u S O 4, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>?

(d) A particulate drawing of a single <math alttext="C u, with a positive 2 charge"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ion is shown in the following box. Draw two <math alttext="H 2 O"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules in the box to show the most likely orientation of <math alttext="H 2 O, liquid"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules around the <math alttext="C u, with a positive 2 charge"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ion.

skill.text: 2.D: Make observations or collect data from representations of laboratory setups or results, while attending to precision where appropriate.
